# CASES 2025: Call for Papers

CASES (International Conference on Compilers, Architecture, and Synthesis for Embedded Systems) is a premier forum where researchers, developers, and practitioners exchange information on the latest advances in compilers and architectures for high-performance, low-power embedded systems. The conference showcases leading-edge research in embedded processor, memory, interconnect, and storage architectures, as well as related compiler techniques targeting performance, power, predictability, security, and reliability issues for both traditional and emerging application domains. Additionally, it invites innovative papers addressing design, synthesis, and optimization challenges in heterogeneous and accelerator-rich architectures.

# Call for Papers

## Important Dates

All deadlines are AoE (Anywhere on Earth).

*   **Full papers due:** **January 31, 2025**
*   **Author Response Period:** **March 11 - 14, 2025**
*   **Author notification:** **April 2, 2025**
*   **Early registration deadline:** **June 22, 2025**
*   **Workshops:** **July 21-22, 2025**
*   **Main Conference:** **July 21-25, 2025**
*   **CAV Award Nomination Deadline:** **March 1, 2025**

## Scope

CAV 2025 is the 37th in a series dedicated to the advancement of the theory and practice of computer-aided formal analysis methods for hardware and software systems. The conference covers the spectrum from theoretical results to concrete applications, with an emphasis on practical verification tools and the algorithms and techniques that are needed for their implementation. CAV considers it vital to continue spurring advances in hardware and software verification while expanding to new domains such as machine learning, autonomous systems, and computer security. The proceedings of the conference will be published in the Springer-Verlag Lecture Notes in Computer Science series. A selection of papers is expected to be invited to a special issue of Formal Methods in System Design and the Journal of the ACM.

### Topics of Interest

Topics of interest include but are not limited to:

*   Algorithms and tools for verifying models and implementations
*   Algorithms and tools for system synthesis
*   Algorithms and tools that combine verification and learning
*   Mathematical and logical foundations of verification and synthesis
*   Specifications and correctness criteria for programs and systems
*   Deductive verification using proof assistants
*   Hardware verification techniques
*   Program analysis and software verification
*   Software synthesis
*   Hybrid systems and embedded systems verification
*   Formal methods for cyber-physical systems
*   Compositional and abstraction-based techniques for verification
*   Probabilistic and statistical approaches to verification
*   Verification methods for parallel and concurrent systems
*   Testing and run-time analysis based on verification technology
*   Decision procedures and solvers for verification and synthesis
*   Applications and case studies in verification and synthesis
*   Verification in industrial practice
*   New application areas for algorithmic verification and synthesis
*   Formal models and methods for security
*   Formal models and methods for biological systems
*   AI safety and explainability using formal methods

Submissions on a wide range of topics are sought, particularly ones that identify new research directions. CAV 2025 is not limited to topics discussed in previous instances of the conference. Authors concerned about the appropriateness of a topic may communicate with the conference chairs prior to submission.

## Submission Categories

Papers in all three categories must be submitted by **January 31, 2025** AoE, and should be in LNCS format. Simultaneous submission to other conferences with proceedings or submission of material that has already been published elsewhere is not allowed. The review process will include a feedback/rebuttal period.

### Regular Papers

*   **Page Limit:** 18 pages max, not counting references and appendices.
*   **Anonymity:** Must be anonymized (full double blind review process). Author names and affiliations must be omitted. References to prior work by authors should be made in the third person. These are firm submission requirements, and any regular paper that does not conform to these requirements will be rejected without review.
*   **Artifact:** Authors of accepted regular papers will be invited (but are not required) to submit a relevant artifact for evaluation by the artifact evaluation committee.

### Tool Papers

*   **Page Limit:** 10 pages max, not counting references.
*   **Anonymity:** Not anonymized (single blind review process).
*   **Content:** Should describe system and implementation aspects of a tool with a large (potential) user base. Papers describing tools that have already been presented will be accepted only if significant and clear enhancements to the tool are reported and implemented.
*   **Artifact:** Provisional acceptance is conditional on successful artifact evaluation at the "functional" level. Authors should contact the Artifact Evaluation chairs to find alternate modes of artifact evaluation if an artifact cannot be submitted.

### Industrial Experience Reports & Case Studies

*   **Page Limit:** 10 pages max, not counting references.
*   **Anonymity:** Not anonymized (single blind review process).
*   **Content:** Expected to describe the use of formal methods techniques in industrial settings or in new application domains. Papers are encouraged to discuss unique challenges of transferring research ideas to real-world settings and reflect on lessons learned.
*   **Artifact:** Authors of accepted Industrial Experience Reports and Case Studies will be invited (but are not required) to submit a relevant artifact for evaluation by the artifact evaluation committee.

## Submission Site

Main submission site is [https://cav2025.hotcrp.com/](https://cav2025.hotcrp.com/)

## CAV Award

The CAV award is given annually at the CAV conference for fundamental contributions to the field of Computer-Aided Verification.

*   **CAV Award Nomination Deadline:** **March 1, 2025**
*   Nominations should be submitted by e-mail to a member of the committee. For details, please see [https://conferences.i-cav.org/2025/award/](https://conferences.i-cav.org/2025/award/).

## Contact

For any questions please contact the PC chairs:

*   Ruzica Piskac (ruzica.piskac@yale.edu)
*   Zvonimir Rakamaric (zrakamar@gmail.com)

# Call for Papers

The **2025 IEEE 21st International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering (CASE)** will be held on **August 17 – August 21, 2025**, in **Los Angeles, California, USA**. The pre-conference workshops are scheduled for **August 17, 2025**.

CASE is the flagship automation conference of the IEEE Robotics and Automation Society (RAS), serving as the primary forum for cross-industry and multidisciplinary research in automation.

## About CASE 2025

The conference theme is **Secured and Trustworthy Automation**. It addresses the increasing reliance of automation systems (e.g., collaborative robotics, smart manufacturing, smart cities) on security and trustworthiness, highlighting the need for research to overcome vulnerabilities and biases.

## Topics

The conference covers a wide range of topics, including but not limited to:

*   Foundation of Automation
*   Human-centered automation
*   Automation in life science and healthcare
*   Sustainability and green automation
*   Automation in agriculture and horticulture
*   Automation in meso, micro and nano-scale
*   Smart building and construction
*   Knowledge-based automation
*   Manufacturing automation
*   Cloud-based automation
*   Big data, data mining and machine learning
*   Privacy and security in automation

## Submission Categories

CASE 2025 invites submissions for:

*   **Regular Papers:** Up to 6 pages (plus 2 extra pages at an additional charge, max 8 pages total). Accepted papers are published in IEEE Xplore.
*   **Special Session Papers:** Similar to regular papers but grouped within specific special sessions. Up to 6 pages (plus 2 extra pages at an additional charge, max 8 pages total). Accepted papers are published in IEEE Xplore.
*   **Special Session Abstracts:** 2 pages. These will have oral presentations but will NOT appear in IEEE Xplore or be indexed.
*   **Work-in-progress and Industry Presentation-only Papers:** Up to 4 pages. For late-breaking results or industry submissions. For Industry Papers, at least one author must be from industry. These will have oral presentations but will NOT appear in IEEE Xplore or be indexed.
*   **Work-in-progress and Industry Presentation-only Papers for Special Sessions:** Up to 4 pages, tailored to special session topics. Oral presentations only, not published or indexed.
*   **T-ASE, T-RO, RA-L and RAM Presentation:** For authors who have published in eligible IEEE RAS journals. Present your published work at CASE 2025. Oral presentation only, not published or indexed.

## Key Dates

*   **Special session proposal submission:** February 8, 2025 (extended to **February 15, 2025**)
*   **Regular and special session full paper submission:** **March 15, 2025** (final deadline)
*   **Industry paper and work-in-progress paper submission:** **April 15, 2025**
*   **Workshop/tutorial proposal submission:** **April 30, 2025**
*   **T-ASE, T-RO, RA-L and RAM presentation submission:** **April 30, 2025**
*   **Paper acceptance notification:** May 30, 2025
*   **Early bird registration:** June 13, 2025
*   **Final paper submission and author registration:** June 27, 2025
*   **Call for Student Volunteers deadline:** July 6, 2025

## Submission Guidelines

*   All papers must be submitted in PDF format.
*   Follow the standard IEEE conference double column format using the provided [LaTeX template](https://2025.ieeecase.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/643/ieeeconf.zip) or [MS Word template](https://2025.ieeecase.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/643/Template-for-Preparation-of-Papers-for-IEEE-Sponsored-Conferences.docx).
*   Submissions are made through the [RAS Papercept submission portal](https://ras.papercept.net/).
*   Authors are required to register a PIN on the Papercept portal. Authors are responsible for submitting papers in the required format and adhering to the templates.

## Review Process

Papers submitted to CASE follow a **single-blinded review system**. Author identities are known to reviewers, but reviewer identities are not disclosed to authors.

## Publication

Accepted **regular papers and special session papers** will be published in the conference program and included in **IEEE Xplore**.

**Special session abstracts, work-in-progress papers, industry papers, and presentation-only papers** will have oral presentations but will **NOT appear in IEEE Xplore** and thus will NOT be indexed on platforms like Scopus.

## Contact Information

Official Contact Email: [case2025@usc.edu](mailto:case2025@usc.edu)

See the website for a list of sponsors, including Gold and Bronze sponsors like USC Viterbi School of Engineering, GeorgiaTech, and The Hoover Institution.

# CC 2025: Call for Papers

The **ACM SIGPLAN 2025 International Conference on Compiler Construction (CC 2025)** is interested in work on processing programs in the most general sense: analyzing, transforming or executing input programs that describe how a system operates, including traditional compiler construction as a special case.

CC 2025 is the **34th edition** of the conference and is an ACM SIGPLAN conference. Proceedings will be made available online in the ACM digital library from one week before to one week after the conference.

## Topics of Interest

Original contributions are solicited on the following topics, including, but not limited to:

*   Compilation and interpretation techniques, including program representation, analysis, and transformation; code generation, optimization, and synthesis; the verification thereof.
*   Run-time techniques, including memory management, virtual machines, and dynamic and just-in-time compilation.
*   Programming tools, including refactoring editors, checkers, verifiers, compilers, debuggers, and profilers.
*   Techniques, ranging from programming languages to micro-architectural support, for specific domains such as secure, parallel, distributed, embedded or mobile environments.
*   Design and implementation of novel language constructs, programming models, and domain-specific languages.
*   Implications to compiler construction from emerging or non-conventional applications (e.g., deep learning, quantum computing, DNA computing, etc.).

## Call for Tool and Practical Experience Papers

This year, CC offers a second category of papers called “Tools and Practical Experience”. Papers in this category must either give a clear account of a tool’s functionality or summarize a practical experience with realistic case studies. The successful evaluation of an artifact is mandatory for a Tool Paper.

Selection criteria include: Originality, Usability, Documentation, Benchmark Repository, Availability, Foundations, and Artifact Evaluation.

## Submission Guidelines

*   **Submission Site:** [https://cc25.hotcrp.com](https://cc25.hotcrp.com)
*   **Format:** All papers must be prepared in **ACM Conference Format** using the 2-column `acmart` format (use options `\documentclass[sigplan,10pt,review,anonymous]{acmart}` for Latex, and `interim-layout.docx` for Word, ensuring 10pt font).
*   **Length:** Maximum of **10 pages** of text (in a typeface no smaller than 10 point) or figures, **NOT INCLUDING references**. References must include the name of all authors.
*   **Supplementary Material:** Authors may submit anonymous supplementary material (e.g., proofs, source code, datasets) in PDF or ZIP format. Reviewer discretion applies.
*   **Anonymity:** CC uses a **double-blind reviewing process**. Submissions must not reveal author identity. Avoid author names/affiliations in the body and use third-person for self-references.
*   **Policies:** Authors must adhere to ACM’s Copyright Policies, SIGPLAN’s Republication Policy, and ACM’s Policy and Procedures on Plagiarism. Authors are subject to ACM’s Policy on Research Involving Human Participants and Subjects. ORCID IDs are required.

## Important Dates (AoE - UTC-12h)

*   **Abstract deadline:** **Tue 5 Nov 2024**
*   **Submission deadline:** **Tue 12 Nov 2024**
*   **Author response:** **Wed 11 Dec - Fri 13 Dec 2024**
*   **Author notification:** **Sat 21 Dec 2024**
*   **Artifact Submission Deadline:** **Fri 17 Jan 2025**
*   **Camera-Ready Deadline:** **Fri 24 Jan 2025**

## Artifact Evaluation

Authors are encouraged to submit their artifacts for the Artifact Evaluation (AE) process, which begins after acceptance notification. The AE committee assesses how artifacts support the paper's claims.

*   **Badge Types:**
    *   **Red badge (Artifact Usable):** Awarded based on usability and robustness (Light-red or Dark-red).
    *   **Blue badge (Results Reproduced):** Awarded if main paper results can be reproduced with the artifact.
    *   **Green Artifact Available Badge:** Awarded if the artifact is publicly available.
*   **Artifact Submission Site:** [https://cc25-ae.hotcrp.com](https://cc25-ae.hotcrp.com)
*   Authors are encouraged to indicate interest in artifact submission upon paper submission.

## Organizers

*   **General Chair:** Daniel Kluss
*   **Program Co-Chairs:** Sara Achour, Jens Palsberg

## Publication

Proceedings will be made available online in the ACM digital library.

## Topics of Interest

Specific topics of interest include but are not limited to the following:

*   **Track 1: Hardware Systems and Networking:** hardware architecture, networking of data centers. Virtualized hardware, Open hardware architectures.
*   **Track 2: Software Systems and Platforms:** Programming models and runtime systems. Resource management and scheduling. Service-oriented architectures. IaaS, PaaS, SaaS. Monitoring and evaluation tools, analysis of system/application performance.
*   **Track 3: Machine Learning (ML) for Systems and Systems for ML:** abstraction, architecture, design and implementation supporting machine learning and artificial intelligence applications. Use of ML/AI applications to enhance the performance of cluster, cloud and Internet-computing systems. ML/AI techniques for workload prediction. Application scheduling, resource placement, resilience in cluster, cloud and Internet-computing systems.
*   **Track 4: Future Compute Continuum and Seamless Ecosystems:** Internet computing frontiers. Future Internet. Osmotic computing. Post- and Non-Von Neumann computing. Quantum computing.
*   **Track 5: Sustainable IT Systems:** abstraction, architecture, design and implementation. Ultra-low power systems architectures. Optimization and analysis in green computing. Environment-friendly computing ecosystems. Power, cooling and thermal awareness. Green edge, IoT, Cloud, datacenter and supercomputers.

# ACM CCS 2025: Call for Papers

The 32nd ACM Conference on Computer and Communications Security (CCS) seeks submissions presenting novel contributions related to all real-world aspects of computer security and privacy.

CCS has **two review cycles** in 2025.

## Review Decisions

*   **Accept:** Papers will be accepted for publication and presentation, possibly after minor changes overseen by a shepherd.
*   **Minor revision:** Promising papers needing minor work (e.g., experiments, proofs) may be resubmitted with revisions for re-evaluation.
*   **Reject:** Papers declined for inclusion. Papers rejected from the first cycle may not be submitted to the second cycle.

At least one author of each accepted paper must register for the conference and present the paper in-person, if possible.

## Paper Submission Information

*   Submissions must be received by 11:59 PM AoE (UTC-12) on the day of the corresponding deadline.
*   Submitted papers must not substantially overlap with papers published or accepted elsewhere, or currently under submission to another journal or conference.
*   All submissions must be properly **anonymized**. Avoid revealing authors' identities and cite previous work by yourself in the third person, or blind the reference itself. Papers not properly anonymized may be rejected without review.
*   Authors may submit up to a maximum of 7 papers for Cycle B.
*   Papers will be evaluated based on their importance to practical aspects of computer and communications security and privacy, novelty, quality of execution, and presentation.
*   For papers raising ethical concerns, authors must convince reviewers that proper procedures have been followed.
*   Submissions may be rejected for being out of scope.
*   No modifications to the author list are allowed after submission.

## Mandatory Reviewing

Authors submitting 3 or more papers may be required to review other papers. Failure to provide requested information may lead to desk rejection.

## Withdrawing Policy

A paper can be withdrawn at any point before reviews are sent to authors. After reviews are sent, withdrawal is not permitted.

## Paper Format

*   Submissions must be a **PDF file** in double-column ACM format using the "sigconf" style.
*   Maximum length: **12 pages**, excluding bibliography, appendices, and supplementary material.
*   Reviewers are not required to read appendices or supplementary material.
*   Do not change the font or margins of the ACM format.
*   Refer to the [sample-sigconf.tex](https://www.acm.org/binaries/content/assets/authors/tex-template/sample-sigconf.tex) and [sample-sigconf.pdf](https://www.acm.org/binaries/content/assets/authors/tex-template/sample-sigconf.pdf) in the ACM package.
*   Submissions not following the required format may be rejected without review.

## Providing Artifacts at Submission Time

Submissions claiming contributions based on artifacts (code, models, data sets) should make them accessible to reviewers unless there are valid reasons not to. An anonymous web link is acceptable if the contents are also anonymized.

## Optional Artifact Evaluation (AE)

Authors of accepted papers are encouraged to submit artifacts for AE. A separate call for artifacts will follow.

## Conference Tracks

The conference features a multi-track format. Authors must select the most relevant track during submission.

*   **Program Co-Chairs:** David Lie (University of Toronto), Véronique Cortier (CNRS, Loria)
*   **Software Security:** Alexandra Dmitrienko, Yinqian Zhang
*   **Web Security:** Yinzhi Cao

*   **Machine Learning and Security:** Neil Gong, Elissa Redmiles, Ben Y. Zhao
*   **Formal Methods and Programming Languages:** Tamara Rezk
*   **Hardware, Side Channels, and Cyber Physical Systems:** Christopher Fletcher, Mengjia Yan
*   **Applied Cryptography:** Marc Fischlin, Dominique Schroeder
*   **Blockchain and Distributed Systems:** Sisi Duan
*   **Privacy and Anonymity:** Catuscia Palamidessi

## Conflicts of Interest

Authors must report any Program Committee members with whom they have a conflict of interest. Mandatory conflicts include current/former advisor/advisee, same institution, close family members, and recent co-authors (within 2 years). Further explanations may be required.

## Policy for Peer-Review Integrity

All participants must adhere to ACM policies against harassment and the ACM Code of Ethics. Violations will be penalized according to ACM policies.

## Important Dates

### First Review Cycle

*   **Abstract submission deadline:** Jan 2, 2025 (Mandatory)
*   **Full paper submission deadline:** Jan 9, 2025
*   **Notification of early-rejection papers:** Feb 10, 2025
*   **Author rebuttal period:** Mar 3—6, 2025
*   **Rebuttal deadline:** Mar 6, 2025

### Second Review Cycle

## Submission Site

*   Cycle A: [https://ccs2025a.hotcrp.com/](https://ccs2025a.hotcrp.com/)
*   Cycle B: [https://ccs2025b.hotcrp.com/](https://ccs2025b.hotcrp.com/)

## Diversity and Inclusion

ACM CCS is committed to promoting diversity and inclusion. Suggestions, concerns, or complaints related to biases or sexual harassment can be reported to the Program Chairs. Authors are encouraged to avoid language or examples that perpetuate marginalization, stereotyping, or erasure of any group.

## Agreements

# CIAC 2025: Call for Papers

The 14th International Symposium on Algorithms and Complexity (CIAC 2025) is scheduled to take place from **June 10 to June 12, 2025**, at **LUISS University, Rome, Italy**.

## Aims and Scope

The conference is intended to provide a forum for researchers working in all aspects of computational complexity and the use, design, analysis, and experimentation of efficient algorithms and data structures.

## Topics

Authors are invited to submit papers presenting original and unpublished research on algorithms and complexity. Typical areas include:

*   Algorithm design and analysis
*   Sequential, parallel, and distributed algorithms
*   Data structures
*   Computational and structural complexity
*   Lower bounds and limitations of algorithms
*   Randomized and approximation algorithms
*   Parameterized algorithms and parameterized complexity classes
*   Smoothed analysis of algorithms
*   Alternatives to the worst-case analysis of algorithms (e.g., algorithms with predictions)
*   On-line computation and competitive analysis
*   Streaming algorithms
*   Quantum algorithms and complexity
*   Algorithms in algebra, geometry, number theory and combinatorics
*   Computational geometry
*   Algorithmic game theory and mechanism design
*   Algorithmic economics (including auctions and contests)
*   Computational learning theory
*   Computational biology and bioinformatics
*   Algorithmic issues in communication networks
*   Algorithms for discrete optimization (including convex optimization)
*   Algorithm engineering

## Important Dates

*   **Deadline for submissions:** November 15, 2024 (AoE) – extended November 22, 2024
*   **Author notification:** January 31, 2025
*   **Camera-ready due:** February 14, 2025
*   **Author Registration:** April 03, 2025
*   **Early Registration:** May 03, 2025

## Submission Guidelines

*   Authors are invited to submit an extended abstract or full paper with at most **15 pages**, excluding the title page and the references. The title page consists of the title of the paper and the abstract. The first section of the paper should start on the next page.
*   The usage of the **LNCS style file is mandatory**. LNCS templates are available at: [https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines](https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines). No changes to font size, page geometry, etc. are permitted.
*   Submissions should be anonymized according to the double-blind review policy.
*   Late submissions and submissions not in the correct format will not be considered.
*   The paper should contain a succinct statement of the issues and their motivation, a summary of the results, a brief explanation of their significance, and a comparison to related work, accessible to non-specialists. Proofs omitted due to space constraints must be put into an appendix, to be read by the PC members at their discretion.
*   Simultaneous submission to other conferences with published proceedings or to journals is not allowed.
*   At least one author of each accepted paper will have to register for the conference. For authors who cannot present their paper in person for a significant reason, the possibility of remote presentation may be offered.

## Submission Site

Submissions will be through EasyChair: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=ciac2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=ciac2025)

## Double-Blind Reviewing

CIAC 2025 will implement a lightweight double-blind reviewing process. Submissions should not reveal the identity of the authors in any way; in particular, authors’ names, affiliations, and email addresses should not appear at the beginning or in the body of the submission. Authors should feel free to disseminate their ideas or draft versions of their paper as they normally would (e.g., making early drafts available on their webpage, or through pre-print dissemination websites such as arXiv). When submitting a paper, please indicate Conflict of Interest (CoI) with PC members.

## PC Submissions

Submissions authored or co-authored by (non-chair) members of the program committee are allowed.

## Proceedings

Accepted papers will be published in the proceedings of the symposium as a volume in Springer LNCS.

## Best Paper Award

Two selected papers will receive the Best Paper Award, sponsored by Springer.

## Contact Information

All questions about submissions should be emailed to Loukas Georgiadis at [loukas@uoi.gr](mailto:loukas@uoi.gr).

# Call for Papers - CHI PLAY 2025

## Overview

The Annual Symposium on Computer-Human Interaction in Play (CHI PLAY) is the premier international and interdisciplinary conference for researchers and professionals across all areas of play, games, and human-computer interaction (HCI), focusing on **player-computer interaction**. CHI PLAY 2025 will be held from **October 13-16, 2025, in Pittsburgh, USA**. The conference aims to highlight and foster discussion of high-quality research in games and HCI, blending academic research papers with interactive play demos, masterclasses, and industry insights.

All accepted submissions will be distributed in the CHI PLAY Conference Proceedings and will be available in the **ACM Digital Library**.

## Full Papers (GAMES Track)

The GAMES track of PACMHCI (CHI PLAY) welcomes research on player-computer interactions, including understanding player experience, contributions on novel designs or implementations, and theoretical advancements. The track also considers research on the effects of technologies, software, or algorithms on player experiences.

## Topics of Interest

We invite authors to submit their best research on all topics relevant to player-computer interactions and digital play. Submission should present original and mature research work. High-quality, elaborated case studies and practice reports with generalizable findings will also be considered. Topics include, but are not limited to:

*   Novel input or output technologies for games and play
*   Studies that contribute to our understanding of player experience of digital play
*   Innovative game mechanics and playful interactions
*   Theoretical contributions on digital play and games
*   Accessible and inclusive design of player-computer interactions
*   Esports, live streaming, and spectator experiences
*   Advances in digital game user research, game evaluation methods, and methods for conducting games research
*   Psychology and typologies of digital games and players
*   Studies of applied, serious, and persuasive digital games (e.g., games and play for health, well-being, and learning)
*   Gamification and motivational design
*   Virtual and augmented reality in games and play
*   New tools for digital game creation and co-creation that directly affect player experience and/or player-computer interactions
*   Game analytics and novel visualizations of player-computer interactions
*   Developer experiences and studies of developers of digital games
*   Applications of human-centered game AI with implications for HCI games research
*   Critical and reflexive approaches to digital games & play design and experience
*   Gaming industry case studies

**Note:** Technical contributions without impact on players or other relevant people in the game community, or systems without a gameful or playful component, are generally out of scope.

## Other Submission Types

CHI PLAY also invites submissions for:

*   Companion Submission Overview & Guidelines
*   Work-in-Progress
*   Perspectives on Play
*   Student Game Design Competition
*   Interactivity
*   Connections
*   Doctoral Consortium
*   Video Guidelines and Technical Requirements

## Important Dates

(all times are 23:59 Anywhere on Earth or AoE)

1.  **Submission deadline:** February 19, 2025
2.  **Notifications given** (accept with minor revisions/revise and resubmit/reject): April 14, 2025
3.  **Revisions due:** June 2, 2025
4.  **Final notifications given:** July 4, 2025

## Submission Process Details

*   PACMHCI GAMES uses the **Precision Conference System (PCS) 2.0**: [https://new.precisionconference.com/submissions](https://new.precisionconference.com/submissions).
*   Select “SIGCHI” as the Society and “CHI PLAY” as the Conference/Journal to make a new submission.
*   **Authorship Policy:** Authors must comply with the ACM Policy on Authorship, including originality, proper attribution, and no concurrent submissions. Author lists cannot be changed after the submission deadline.
*   **Confidentiality:** Submitted material confidentiality will be maintained.
*   **ORCID ID:** Authors are strongly encouraged to obtain an ORCID ID for the publishing process.

## Formatting and Length

*   PACMHCI GAMES uses the **ACM Journals Primary Article Template**, available for LaTeX (and Overleaf) and Word: [https://dl.acm.org/journal/pacmhci/submission-templates](https://dl.acm.org/journal/pacmhci/submission-templates).
*   No minimum or maximum page length is imposed; reviewers weigh contribution relative to length. Typical papers are under 10,000 words (approx. 17-20 pages single-column), excluding references and appendices.

## Anonymous Review Policy

*   Submissions must have authors’ names and affiliations removed, and avoid obvious identifying statements.
*   Grant information that identifies authors/institutions should be removed.
*   Citations to authors' own relevant work should be anonymized (e.g., "Prior work by [authors]").
*   Papers that violate the anonymization policy will be desk rejected.

## Revision Cycles and Decisions

*   **Accept with Minor Revisions:** Requires minor changes; final version due by revision deadline.
*   **Revise and Resubmit:** Requires major changes; revised manuscript due by revision deadline for re-review. Not all resubmissions are guaranteed acceptance.
*   **Reject:** Not acceptable in current form or unable to complete revisions.
*   **Desk Reject:** For submissions that are incomplete, non-anonymized, concurrent, out of scope, improperly formatted, or of low quality/substance.

## Contribution Type for Review Handling

Authors can indicate primary and secondary contribution types for reviewer assignment (e.g., Empirical-Qualitative, Artefact-Technical, Theoretical).

## Open and Transparent Science

Authors are encouraged to submit supplementary material (e.g., interview guides, videos, pre-registrations on OSF) and use open access repositories. Supplementary materials must be anonymized.

## ACM Policy on Use of Generative AI

Generative AI use is permitted but must be disclosed, and authors are responsible for the content and plagiarism. AI tools cannot be listed as authors.

## ACM Publications Policy on Research Involving Human Participants

Authors must adhere to ethical and legal standards for research involving human participants, including informed consent and minimization of harm. A description of participant handling will be required.

## Video Figures

*   **Mandatory** for submissions involving custom-built games or systems not freely available.
*   Showcase core mechanics or provide a playthrough.
*   Max three minutes long.
*   Submissions lacking this may be desk rejected if the system cannot be assessed.

## Presenting at the CHI PLAY Conference

Accepted papers will be invited to present at the ACM CHI PLAY conference in Fall 2025. Presentation is strongly recommended but not required for publication in PACM HCI.

## More Information

For more information, visit [https://chiplay.acm.org/2025/](https://chiplay.acm.org/2025/).

# Call for Papers (General Information for CICLing)

The International Conference on Intelligent Text Processing and Computational Linguistics (CICLing) is a series of conferences devoted to computational linguistics (CL), intelligent text processing, natural language processing (NLP), human language technologies (HLT), natural-language human-computer interaction (HCI), and speech processing and speech recognition (SR).

## Scope and Topics of Interest

CICLing covers a broad range of topics including, but not limited to:

*   Text processing
*   Computational morphology, tagging, stemming
*   Syntactic analysis, parsing, shallow parsing, chunking
*   Recognizing textual entailment
*   Ambiguity resolution
*   Semantic analysis, pragmatics
*   Lexicon, lexical resources, dictionaries, machine-readable dictionaries (MRD)
*   Grammar, anaphora resolution
*   Word sense disambiguation (WSD)
*   Machine translation (MT)
*   Information retrieval (IR), information extraction (IE)
*   Document handling, document classification, text classification
*   Text summarization, text mining (TM)

# Call for Full Research Papers

The Conference on Information and Knowledge Management (CIKM) provides a unique venue for industry and academia to present and discuss state-of-the-art research on artificial intelligence, search and discovery, data mining, and database systems. CIKM 2025 will take place between **November 10-14, 2025** in **Coex, Seoul, Korea**.

## Topics of Interest

We encourage submissions of high-quality research papers on the general areas of artificial intelligence, data science, databases, information retrieval, and knowledge management. Topics of interest include, but are not limited to, the following areas:

*   Data acquisition and processing (e.g., IoT Data, Data Quality, Data Privacy, Mitigating Biases, Data Wrangling, Data exploration, Data Preparation, Valuation, and Trading)
*   Data Integration and aggregation (e.g., Semantic Processing, data provenance, data linkage, data fusion, knowledge graph, data warehousing, data lake, privacy and security, modeling, information credibility)
*   Efficient data processing (e.g., serverless, data-intensive computing, database systems, indexing and compression, architectures, distributed data systems, dataspaces, customized hardware)
*   Special data processing (e.g., multilingual text, sequential, stream, time series, spatio-temporal, (knowledge) graph, multimedia, scientific, and social media data)
*   Analytics and machine learning (e.g., OLAP, data mining, machine learning and AI, scalable analysis algorithms, algorithmic biases, event detection and tracking, algorithmic interpretability)
*   Neural Information and knowledge processing (e.g., graph neural networks, domain adaptation, transfer learning, network architectures, neural ranking, neural recommendation, and neural prediction)
*   Information access and retrieval (e.g., Information Retrieval with Large Language Models, Question Answering and Dialogue Systems, Open-ended Question Answering Systems, Generation of Knowledge Graphs from Unstructured data, Retrieval Models, Query Processing, Personalization, Recommender Systems, Filtering Systems)
*   Users and interfaces for information systems (e.g., user behavior analysis, user interface design, perception of biases, interactive information retrieval, interactive analysis, spoken interfaces)
*   Evaluation (e.g., performance studies, benchmarks, online and offline evaluation, best practices)
*   Crowdsourcing (e.g. task assignment, worker reliability, optimization, trustworthiness, transparency, crowdsourcing in the era of large language models)
*   Mining multi-modal content (e.g., natural language processing, speech recognition, computer vision, content understanding, knowledge extraction, knowledge representations)
*   Data presentation (e.g., visualization, summarization, readability, VR, speech input/output)
*   Fairness, Ethics, and Explainability in Information and Knowledge Management (e.g., fairness, accountability, ethics, explainability)
*   Applications (e.g., urban systems, biomedical and health informatics, legal informatics, crisis informatics, computational social science, data-enabled discovery, social networks, education, business)
*   Generative AI for Data and Knowledge Management (e.g., GenAI for structured and unstructured data processing, GenAI for data synthesis and simulation, GenAI for information summarization, content creation, and visualization)
*   Resource Efficient Generative AI models for knowledge management (e.g., model compression, distributed learning, and leveraging edge computing to reduce computational overhead.)

*   **Paper Format:** Manuscripts should be submitted in PDF format, using the 2-column ACM sigconf template. See: [https://www.acm.org/publications/proceedings-template](https://www.acm.org/publications/proceedings-template).
*   **Page Limits:** Full papers cannot exceed 9 pages, including an appendix, plus unlimited pages for the GenAI Usage Disclosure section and references.

AI tools may be used for light editing (e.g., grammar checks, word autocorrect), but text produced entirely by generative AI models is not allowed.

*   **Dual Submission Policy:** Submitting identical or substantially similar versions of papers to other conferences or venues is not allowed. Abstract submissions are allowed if the full paper review concludes by the final deadline. Preprints (e.g., arXiv) are allowed if anonymized.

# IEEE Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Data Mining (CIDM) 2025 - Call for Papers

IEEE SSCI is widely recognized for cultivating the interchange of state-of-the-art theories and sophisticated algorithms within the broad realm of Computational Intelligence Applications. The Symposia provide for cross-pollination of research concepts, fostering an environment that facilitates future inter and intra collaborations.

The 2025 event marks a significant milestone in the evolution of IEEE SSCI, launching the newly restructured biennial Symposia Series featuring ten dedicated Applied Computational Intelligence Symposia:

*   2025 IEEE Symposia on CI for Energy, Transport and Environmental Sustainability (IEEE CIETES)
*   2025 IEEE Symposia on CI in Engineering / Cyber Physical Systems (IEEE CIES)
*   2025 IEEE Symposia on CI in Image, Signal Processing and Synthetic Media (IEEE CISM)
*   2025 IEEE Symposia on CI in Artificial Life and Cooperative Intelligent Systems (IEEE ALIFE-CIS)
*   2025 IEEE Symposia on CI in Security, Defence and Biometrics (IEEE CISDB)
*   2025 IEEE Symposia on CI in Health and Medicine (IEEE CIHM)
*   2025 IEEE Symposia on CI for Financial Engineering and Economics (IEEE CiFer)
*   2025 IEEE Symposia on CI in Natural Language Processing and Social Media (IEEE CI-NLPSoMe)
*   2025 IEEE Symposia on Trustworthy, Explainable and Responsible CI (IEEE CITreX)
*   2025 IEEE Symposia for Multidisciplinary Computational Intelligence Incubators (IEEE MCII)

## Venue

IEEE SSCI 2025 is hosted in **Trondheim, Norway**, offering a stunning winter location with opportunities for skiing, experiencing longer days, milder weather, and potentially seeing the Northern Lights. The downtown area is easily walkable to attractions, shopping, and restaurants.

## Late Submission Opportunities

IEEE SSCI 2025 offers several submission options for late-breaking research:

*   **Late-Breaking Papers:** Submit an extended abstract of up to 2 pages to share preliminary research, ideas, or critiques, fostering interactive discussions.
*   **Poster-Only Submissions:** Submit a short abstract (up to 250 words) to present early-stage concepts or challenges for constructive feedback.
*   **Journal to Conference (J2C) Submissions:** Provide a summary (up to 1 page) of recent journal articles relevant to SSCI themes, promoting broader engagement with your research.

For more instructions on each kind of submission, including page limitations and submission format, please see [submission instructions](?ui=submission-instructions).

# CDVE 2025: Call for Papers

The Cooperative Design, Visualization, and Engineering (CDVE) conference series, now in its 22nd year, invites submissions of original papers focusing on the "cooperative" concept. The conference will be held in **Bangkok, Thailand, from October 19-22, 2025**.

## Conference Focus

The conference scope encompasses multiple users, multiple locations, multiple units, and multiple sensors, with a strong emphasis on cooperative aspects.

## Major Areas and Topics

### Cooperative Design (CD)

*   Multiple user, multiple location collaborative design applications
*   Concurrent design, collaborative editing, real-time user interactions
*   Cooperative User Experience (UX) design
*   Demonstrating feasibility and applicability in CD
*   Multi-modal interface design (e.g., cooperative design using interactive tabletops and surfaces)
*   Design for total life cycle support: from design to manufacturing or construction
*   Cooperative design analysis, verification, integration, and interoperability, standards
*   Scenarios, case studies of cooperative design in mechanical engineering, aero-space engineering, building architecture, engineering and construction, automobile, microelectronics, software engineering, entertainment, and other areas
*   Special issues in cooperative design

### Cooperative Visualization (CV)

*   System architecture, prototypes, user interfaces for CV: web applications, textual and multimedia 2D, 3D desktop interfaces, 3D virtual world environments, and multiple user embedded systems.
*   Visualization for multiple users, multiple locations, concurrent visualization
*   Cooperative visual analytics and communication
*   Large scale, big data storage, access, exploration, and manipulation for cooperative visualization
*   Multi-resolution and other efficient computer graphics, visualization algorithms for cooperative visualization
*   Visualization in multiple user games, networked games, simulation visualization for multiple users

### Cooperative Engineering (CE)

*   Collaborative process planning, scheduling, control, conformance testing and interoperability checking, cooperative decision making.
*   Human-machine interfaces, frameworks, reference models, architectures, tools, and systems for CE
*   Concurrent prototyping, manufacturing, and engineering.
*   Concurrent process modeling, product modeling, reference models, business models, data representations, and standards.
*   Integration and interoperability, intelligent infrastructures, and automated methods for integrating systems, multi-level integration, enterprise integration
*   Long-term large scale project data archiving, access, concurrent data control for CE
*   Smart grids
*   Industrial scenarios, case studies of CE: in mechanical engineering, aerospace engineering, AEC (architecture, engineering and construction), automobile, microelectronics, and others
*   Methods, applications for total life cycle support: from conceptual design to manufacturing and construction

### Cooperative Applications (CA)

*   Human computer interface for cooperative working
*   Cooperation between humans and autonomous systems
*   Social networks
*   Crowd sourcing
*   Collective intelligence
*   Cooperative learning, multi-modal learning
*   Multiple user gaming
*   Multiple platform payment systems
*   Multimodal user interface for cooperation
*   Cooperative decision making
*   Cooperative Internet of Things (IoT)
*   Nano networks, nano-communication, nano sensors
*   Collaborative Information seeking
*   Information integration in sensor networks
*   Collaborations in emergency response and disaster management
*   Collaborative mobile systems, group interaction in mobile systems and mobility communities
*   Collaborative simulation
*   Collaborative robots and human-robot interaction, social robots
*   Collaboration technologies and systems for healthcare
*   Web-based cooperation tools, cooperative web design (e.g., Wikis)
*   Cooperative service-oriented applications
*   Other cooperative applications

### Basic Theories, Methods, and Technologies that support CDVE (BT)

*   Modeling of group behavior
*   Distributed systems, grid systems, real-time systems, groupware
*   Cooperation issues in metaverse, digital twins
*   Cloud computing, edge computing for cooperative work
*   Fog computing for cooperative storage, cooperative working
*   Big data processing, fusion
*   Multi-sensor data processing, fusion
*   Neural networks for CDVE
*   Blockchains, distributed ledger technology
*   Algorithms, architectures, frameworks, platforms for CDVE
*   Data consistency, concurrent processing, middleware
*   Agent-based methods, conversational agents, hybrid conversational agents combining human and machine intelligence (cooperative CAs)
*   Collaborative and multi-mode working environments
*   Design patterns, re-usability, and component-based methods
*   Communication, transport, application protocols for CDVE
*   Internet computing, web environment for collaborative working
*   Knowledge management, information systems, large databases, data-mining
*   Semantic Technologies for Information-Integrated Collaboration
*   Ontology for information sharing, cooperative applications
*   Security for CDVE
*   Human machine interaction for CDVE
*   Artificial intelligence for CDVE

## Special Issue Opportunity

CDVE2025 Special Issue on IEEE Systems, Man, and Cybernetics Magazine: "Advance in cooperative design, visualization, engineering, and other cooperative applications." The best quality papers from CDVE2025 will be selected for publication. To be considered, authors must submit a paper to CDVE2025 first.

## Deadlines

*   **Submission:** (Extended by 2 weeks for the special issue call)
*   **Notification:** (Not specified in Call for Papers section, but typically follows submission)
*   **Registration:** Begins now (Early registration welcome for accepted papers or general participation).

## Submission Process

*   All submissions should be made through the EasyChair system: **cdve2025@easychair.org**.
*   Papers should be original and not under review elsewhere.

## Publication

All accepted full papers and short papers with valid registration will be published in the **Lecture Notes in Computer Science (LNCS)** series by Springer.

Each paper will have an independent DOI and will be indexed in major systems including:

*   Conference Proceedings Citation Index (CPCI)

*   Scopus
*   ACM Digital Library
*   IO-Port
*   dblp
*   MathSciNet
*   Google Scholar

# Call for Papers: CISIS 2025

The 18th International Conference on Computational Intelligence in Security for Information Systems (CISIS 2025) aims to offer a meeting opportunity for academic and industry-related researchers from the fields of Computational Intelligence, Information Security, Cybersecurity, and Data Mining. The conference is intended to catalyze and aggregate efforts towards intelligent, flexible systems, particularly in mission-critical domains.

CISIS 2025 is part of the **International Joint Conferences HAIS-SOCO-CISIS-ICEUTE & STARTUP OLÉ** and will be held on **16-17 October 2025** in **Salamanca, Spain**.

## Topics of Interest

*   Computational Intelligence
*   Information Security
*   Cybersecurity
*   Data Mining

For a detailed list of topics, please visit: [http://cisisconference.eu/topics/](http://cisisconference.eu/topics/)

## Submission Types and Guidelines

*   **Paper Length:** Papers must be prepared according to the **LNNS style template** and must be no more than **ten (10) pages** long, including figures and bibliography. Additional pages (over 10 pages) will be charged **150 euros** for each page.
*   **Presentation:** All accepted papers must be presented by one of the authors, who must register for the conference and pay the fee.
*   **Format:** Templates are available at [http://sococonference.eu/paper-submission-publication](http://sococonference.eu/paper-submission-publication).

## Publication

*   CISIS’25 proceedings will be published by **Springer** in a special volume of **Lecture Notes in Networks and Systems (LNNS)**.
*   Indexed by **SCOPUS, INSPEC, WTI Frankfurt eG, zbMATH, SCImago**.

## Special Issues

All accepted papers (submitted to general track and special sessions) will be considered for possible inclusion in a special issue of **Neurocomputing (ELSEVIER)** (2024 JCR Impact Factor: 5.5 – Q1).

## Call for Special Sessions

Researchers are invited to submit proposals for organizing Special Sessions. Proposals are due by **15th March 2025**.

**Conditions for Organizers:**

*   Select a topic of interest to conference delegates.
*   Obtain a minimum of 5 papers for the session, with at least 60% by authors not affiliated with the session chairs or reviewers.
*   Manage the review process for session papers according to deadlines.
*   Provide suitable reviewers.
*   Ensure final paper versions are uploaded before the deadline.
*   Attend the conference and chair the session.
*   Disseminate the call for papers for the special session.

*   Title of the special session and selected conference (SOCO’25, CISIS’25, and ICEUTE’25).

*   List of at least 10 international reviewers (including chairs) from at least three different universities (name, family name, email, affiliation).

# CICM 2025: Call for Papers

The 18th Conference on Intelligent Computer Mathematics (CICM 2025) will be held from **October 6-11, 2025**, in **Brasilia, Brazil**.

## About CICM

CICM brings together communities working on theoretical and practical solutions for mathematical applications such as computation, deduction, knowledge management, and user interfaces. It offers a venue for discussing problems and solutions in these areas and their integration.

## Topics of Interest

We are inviting formal submissions on all topics relating to intelligent computer mathematics, in particular, but not limited to:

*   theorem proving and computer algebra
*   mathematical knowledge management
*   digital mathematical libraries

A comprehensive list of topics of interest can be found on the conference website: [https://cicm-conference.org/2025/cicm.php?event=&menu=topics](https://cicm-conference.org/2025/cicm.php?event=&menu=topics)

## Invited Speakers

*   Fabian Huch, Technische Universität München (TUM)
*   Assia Mahboubi, INRIA, Nantes
*   Daniele Nantes Sobrinho, University of Brasilia (UnB)
*   Josef Urban, Czech Institute of of Informatics, Robotics and Cybernetics (CIIRC)
*   Joint Invited Speaker with LSFA 2025: Temur Kutsia, Research Institute for Symbolic Computation (RISC), Johannes Kepler University

## Formal Paper Submissions

Formal submissions will be reviewed rigorously and accepted papers will be published in a volume of Springer LNAI:

*   **Regular papers:** (up to 15 pages + bibliography) present novel research results.
*   **Project and survey papers:** (up to 15 pages + bibliography) summarize existing results.
*   **System and dataset descriptions:** (4 to 5 pages + bibliography) present digital artifacts.

## Doctoral Symposium

*   **Submission Type:** Two-page abstracts describing the focus and research questions of the PhD theses, along with details on completed research tasks and remaining research plans.
*   **Additional Submission:** A two-page CV of the applicant detailing background information (name, university, supervisor), education, employments, and relevant research experience.
*   **Chairs:** Claudia Nalon (UnB Brasilia) and Marcelo Finger (USP Sao Paulo).

## Important Dates

*   **Notification to candidates:** September 15, 2025

## Submissions

All submissions should be made via EasyChair at [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=cicm2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=cicm2025) using the Springer LNCS style files: [https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines](https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines)

If software or data is relevant to a paper, a link that provides access to the software/data must be provided to enable reproduction of results.

## Best Papers

CICM 2025 honors the best paper and best student paper with respect to reviews and program committee discussions with an award.

# Call for Papers for CHES 2025

The Workshop on Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems (CHES) is the premier venue for research in all aspects of cryptographic hardware and embedded systems. CHES 2025 will be held in **Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia**, from **September 14-18, 2025**.

Papers accepted and published by the *Transactions on Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems (TCHES)* journal during the 2025 volumes will be presented at CHES 2025.

## Scope and Topics

CHES focuses on research pertaining to **cryptographic hardware and embedded systems**. This includes, but is not limited to, the design and analysis of cryptographic primitives, implementations of cryptographic algorithms, attacks against implementations, and defenses against such attacks in various hardware and embedded contexts.

## Submission Process

Submissions to CHES are handled through the *Transactions on Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems (TCHES)* journal, which operates on a continuous submission model with four fixed deadlines per year. Authors are encouraged to submit their work to any of the upcoming TCHES volumes that align with the CHES 2025 presentation schedule.

Submissions are made via the dedicated submission portal for TCHES. Further details on the submission process, including formatting requirements and guidelines, are available on the [paper submission page](https://ches.iacr.org/2025/papersubmission.php).

# CGO 2025: Call for Papers

The International Symposium on Code Generation and Optimization (CGO’25) will be held in **Las Vegas, USA**, from **March 1st to March 5th, 2025**. CGO is the premier venue to bring together researchers and practitioners working at the interface of hardware and software on a wide range of optimization and code generation techniques and related issues. The conference spans the spectrum from purely static to fully dynamic approaches, and from pure software-based methods to specific architectural features and support for code generation and optimization.

CGO will be held in conjunction with PPoPP, CC, and HPCA.

CGO uses a **two-submission-per-year model**. Papers submitted to the first round can either be directly accepted, rejected, or invited to submit a revised version for the second round.

## Topics

Original contributions are solicited on, but not limited to, the following topics:

*   Code Generation, Translation, Transformation, and Optimization for performance, energy, virtualization, portability, security, or reliability concerns, and architectural support
*   Efficient execution of dynamically typed and higher-level languages
*   Optimization and code generation for emerging programming models, platforms, domain-specific languages
*   Dynamic/static, profile-guided, feedback-directed, and machine learning-based optimization
*   Static, Dynamic, and Hybrid Analysis for performance, energy, memory locality, throughput or latency, security, reliability, or functional debugging
*   Program characterization methods
*   Profiling and instrumentation techniques; architectural support
*   Novel and efficient tools
*   Compiler design, practice and experience
*   Compiler abstraction and intermediate representations
*   Vertical integration of language features, representations, optimizations, and runtime support for parallelism
*   Solutions that involve cross-layer (HW/OS/VM/SW) design and integration
*   Deployed dynamic/static compiler and runtime systems for general purpose, embedded system and Cloud/HPC platforms
*   Parallelism, heterogeneity, and reconfigurable architectures
*   Optimizations for heterogeneous or specialized targets, GPUs, SoCs, CGRA and Quantum Computers
*   Compiler support for vectorization, thread extraction, task scheduling, speculation, transaction, memory management, data distribution and synchronization

## Submission Guidelines

### General Requirements

*   The paper must be original material that has not been previously published or is currently under review by another conference or journal.
*   Submissions are limited to **eleven (11) letter-size (8.5"x11") pages**, excluding references. An appendix is allowed with no page limit, but reviewers are not required to read it. Papers must be self-contained.
*   **Format:** ACM format (using the sample-sigplan.tex template).
*   **Language:** English.
*   **File Format:** PDF only.
*   **Printing:** Must be formatted for black-and-white printers; readable graphs are essential; pages must be numbered.
*   **Fonts:** Use of Times, Helvetica, Courier, and Symbol is suggested.

### Double-Blind Review

*   Papers are to be submitted for double-blind review. Author names and identifying information must be removed.
*   Reference prior work by yourself in the third person, as if extending someone else's research.

### Author Responsibilities

*   Authors must register all their conflicts of interest on the submission site.
*   ORCID IDs are required for publication.
*   Authors are subject to all ACM Publications Policies.

## Tool and Practical Experience Papers

*   This category requires either a clear account of a tool's functionality or a summary of practical experience with realistic case studies.
*   **Artifact Evaluation:** Mandatory for Tool Papers; optional for Practical Experience Papers. Successful evaluation is required for final acceptance.
*   **Criteria:** Originality, Usability, Documentation, Benchmark Repository, Availability, Foundations, Artifact Evaluation.
*   Same page limit (11 pages excluding references) and format as regular papers.

## Geographic Diversity and Inclusion

*   Remote presentation is allowed for authors unable to travel due to reasons beyond their control (e.g., visa issues).
*   Efforts will be made to make attendance affordable, especially for students from under-represented countries.

## Artifact Evaluation

*   A separate committee assesses artifacts to improve reproducibility. Papers with successful AE will receive a seal of approval.
*   Authors can indicate interest in submitting an artifact at the time of paper submission.

*   [https://cgo25-second-round.hotcrp.com/](https://cgo25-second-round.hotcrp.com/)
